qas.question: Where is Eduardo Bonilla-Silver a Sociology professor?
What does Bonilla-Silva contend racism is about more than anything else?
Who does Bonilla-Silva think is the dominant racial group?
What idea does color-blind racism thrive on?

answers.text: that race is no longer an issue

qas.question: What exists between the alleged color-blindness of most whites and the persistence of a system of inequality?

context: Eduardo Bonilla-Silva, Sociology professor at <a0_0>Duke University<a0_0/>, remarks, "I contend that racism is, more than anything else, a matter of <a1_0>group power<a1_0/>; it is about a dominant racial group (<a2_0>whites<a2_0/>) striving to maintain its systemic advantages and minorities fighting to subvert the racial status quo."  The types of practices that take place under this new color-blind racism is subtle, institutionalized, and supposedly not racial. Color-blind racism thrives on the idea <a3_0>that race is no longer an issue<a3_0/> in the United States. There are <a4_0>contradictions<a4_0/> between the alleged color-blindness of most whites and the persistence of a color-coded system of inequality.
